				Malta to amend strict anti-abortion laws			

				The announcement came after an American woman, Andrea Prudente, was refused an abortion in Malta despite the risk to her life.

						People gather in front of the Prime Minister's Office for an abortion rights rally in Valletta, Malta | Joanna Demarco/Getty Images					







			November 16, 2022		

			6:03 pm CET		



	
	By 
			
			Sarah-Taïssir Bencharif		





Malta is set to amend its abortion laws, allowing doctors to terminate a pregnancy when the woman’s health or life are at grave risk. 
The announcement was made Wednesday by Health Minister Chris Fearne, Justice Minister Jonathan Attard, and Parliamentary Secretary for Reforms and Equality Rebecca Buttigieg. 
The amendments to the criminal code aim to ensure the legal protection of medical professionals by clarifying that terminations to safeguard the health of the woman will not be considered a crime. These amendments, which were instigated by doctors, are expected to be tabled in parliament early next week.
As it stands, Malta has the strictest laws in the bloc, with abortion illegal under any circumstances. In practice, termination of pregnancies that pose a serious threat to the health or life of the woman are “already a standard practice at Mater Dei Hospital [the largest hospital in Malta],” the officials said in a statement. The new amendments would offer "peace of mind" to medical professionals, said Buttigieg.Wednesday's announcement comes after an American woman, Andrea Prudente, was refused an abortion in Malta despite the risk to her life. The woman filed a constitutional case against the country’s health minister and parliamentary secretary for reforms and equality. She was eventually able to fly to Spain for further care.
